OVERVIEW:
The Lockman series consists of deep, well drained soils formed in
residuum and colluvium from igneous rock.  Lockman soils are on
mountainsides and have slopes of 5 to 60 percent.  Permeability is
moderately rapid.  The average annual precipitation is about 20 inches,
and the average annual air temperature is about 38 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Xeric Haplocryolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Lockman stony sandy loam in woodland, (Colors are for
dry soil unless otherwise noted).
Oil--2 to 1 inch; Undecomposed leaves, needles, twigs and cones.
0i2--1 to 0 inch; Partially decomposed needles, leaves and twigs.
A--0 to 13 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) stony sandy loam,
very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; weak medium subangular blocky
structure that parts to weak fine granular; soft, very friable; many
very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine
interstitial pores; about 30 to 40% rounded 5 to 10 cm. krotivinas that
are brown (10YR 5/3) dry and very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist;
slightly acid (pH 6.3); clear smooth boundary.  (10 to 15 inches thick)
Bw--13 to 19 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) sandy loam, brown
moist; (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure;
slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky; many very fine and fine, few
medium and coarse roots; many fine tubular pores; 5 percent pebbles;
about 30 percent rounded 5 to 10 cm, krotivinas that are light grayish
brown (10YR 6/2) dry and grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; moderately
acid (pH 6.0); gradual smooth boundary.  (5 to 9 inches thick)
C1--19 to 29 inches; pale olive (5Y 6/3) sandy loam, olive (5Y 5/3)
moist; massive; slightly hard, friable; common very fine and fine, few
medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine, few medium and coarse
roots; many very fine and fine tubular pores; slightly acid (pH 6.5);
abrupt smooth boundary.  (9 to 11 inches thick)
C2--29 to 39 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) sandy loam,
yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable; few
very fine and fine roots; many fine and medium tubular pores;
moderately acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 12 inches
thick)
C3--39 to 48 inches;  light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) very cobbly
sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; massive; soft, friable;
few very fine and fine roots; common very fine interstitial pores; 25
percent and 15 percent cobbles; moderately acid (pH 6.0).
R--48 inches; andesite bedrock.

TYPE LOCATION.content:
TYPE LOCATION:  Camas County, Idaho; about 5 miles west and 6 miles
north of Corral; 1100 feet east and 1900 feet south of the northwest
corner section 16, T. 1 N., R. 12 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Depth to soft granitic bedrock - 40 to 60 inches or more
Average annual soil temperature - 38 to 43 degrees F.
Average summer soil temperature - 44 to 47 degrees F.
Reaction - moderately acid to neutral
Cr horizon - may be present in some pedons
Base saturation - 50 to 75 percent
Clay content in control section - 5 to 15 percent
A horizons
Value - 3 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist
Chroma - 1 or 2 dry or moist
Oi horizons - absent in some pedons
Bw horizons
Value - 5 through 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist
Chroma - 2 through 4 dry or moist
Texture - SL or GR-SL
Clay - 5 to 15 percent
C horizons
Hue - 10YR through 5Y
Value - 6 through 8 dry, 4 though 6 moist
Chroma - 3 through 6 dry or moist
Texture - SL, GR-SL, CB-SL, GR-LS, CBV-SL
Clay - 3 to 12 percent

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Arkson, Branham, Clergern, Coski,
Dinnen, Sawcreek, Sula, and Teoculli series.  Arkson soils lack a
cambic horizon have 20-35 percent rock fragments and occur in a 30 to
40 inch precipitation.  Branham and Sawcreek are moderately deep to
bed-rock.  Clergern soils have 5YR and redder colors and a base
saturation of more than 75 percent.  Coski soils have a cambic that is
15 to 25 inches thick with few clay films.  Dinnen soils have a layer
immediately under the surface layer that is extremely hard when dry.
Sula soils are very fine, sandy loam or silt loam in the upper part of
the control section and are moderately permeable.  Teoculli soils lack
a cambic, are moderately permeable and have less than 35 percent fine
sand and coarse.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Lockman soils are on mountainsides and have slopes
of 5 to 60 percent.  These soils formed in residuum and colluvium from
igneous rock.  Elevation is 5200 to 8200 feet.  The climate has cold
moist winters and cool summers.  Average annual precipitation is 18 to
24 inches most of which falls as snow and early spring rain.  The
average annual temperature is 36 to 40 degrees F.  The frost-free
period is less than 60 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Earcree, Elkcreek,
Gaib, Moonstone, and Roanhide soils.  Earcree soils have mollic
epipedons greater than 16 inches thick.  Elkcreek, Moonstone, and
Roanhide soils are 20 to 40 inches deep. Gaib soils are 10 to 20 inches
deep.  Earcree soils occur on the same landscape as Lockman.  Elkcreek,
Gaib, Moonstone, and Roanhide soils are on south and west-facing
mountainsides.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content:
DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow to very rapid runoff;
permeability is moderately rapid.

USE AND VEGETATION.content:
USE AND VEGETATION:  Used mainly for woodland.  Vegetation is
Douglas-Fir, Ponderosa pine, serviceberry, and heartleaf arnica.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content:
DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Lockman soils are of limited extent in south
central Idaho.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Portland, Oregon

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon
are:
Mollic epipedon - the zone from the soil surface to approximately 13
inches (A horizon).
Particle size control section - the zone from 10 to 40 inches (part of
the A horizon, Bw, C1, C2, and part of the C3 horizon).
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
